docs.title: Welcome to ED3N Hydro Boards
docs.text:
Start growing smarter—without a tangle of breadboards or weeks of wiring. ED3N boards give everyone from weekend hobbyists to research labs a plug-and-play control platform for hydroponics.

Why we built them To make the first step into hydro automation as easy as stacking a HAT on a Pi—or, with our Pro board, skipping the Pi entirely.

docs.title: Board Line-up at a Glance
docs.text:
Board Core Idea Key Specs Best For ED3N Hydro Basic “Smart start” HAT • Raspberry Pi HAT• 1 × 12 V ⎓ in → 8 × 12 V/12 W pump outputs• 8 × JST-PH I²C sensor ports Hobby growers • STEM classes • First prototypes ED3N Hydro Room to grow • All Basic features• Powers the Pi from the board• Extra I²C & power ports• Native Atlas Scientific EZO™ support Makers scaling up • Classroom research • Long-term projects ED3N Hydro Pro Standalone, rugged • On-board computer (no Pi needed)• Industrial-grade parts, conformal coating• More JST expansion for future add-ons Commercial grows • Research labs • Harsh-env installs

(Full electrical specs are on each board’s page.)

docs.title: How to Get Started
docs.text:
1. Choose your board from the table above.
  2. Order on Amazon → search “ED3N Hydro Basic/Hydro/Pro” (listings live soon).
  3. Plug in pumps & sensors, follow the quick-start guide, and grow!

Boards arrive fully assembled, firmware-flashed, and electrically tested—no soldering required.

docs.title: Hydro Lite
docs.text:
A compact control board for automated hydroponic systems. It drives eight 12 V nutrient-dosing pumps plus one 12 V master pump, letting you pre-mix before filling the reservoir. No soldering is required—boards arrive fully assembled and electrically tested (sold on Amazon).

!!! tip "Quick links" * Schematic PDF * Buy pre-assembled on Amazon (coming soon)

docs.title: Features
docs.text: MCU ATtiny1624 @ 16 MHz (Optiboot) Pump outputs 9 × N-MOSFET (8 nutrient, 1 master) @ 12 V / 5 A each Supply 9 – 15 V DC barrel jack Sensor bus 3-pin JST-PH I²C (3 .3 V logic)

docs.title: Controlling the Pumps
docs.text:
Each MOSFET channel is wired to a dedicated Raspberry Pi GPIO pin. Set the pin HIGH to energise the MOSFET and run the pump; set it LOW to stop.

Connector label Pi GPIO Master Pump 6 Pump 1 13 Pump 2 26 Pump 3 16 Pump 4 12 Pump 5 5 Pump 6 25 Pump 7 24 Pump 8 23

docs.title: Calibration workflow
docs.text:
1. Prime each pump tubing with water or nutrient.
  2. In your control software (Python, Node-RED, etc.) turn one pump on for a known time — e.g. 30 seconds.
  3. Measure the volume dispensed (graduated cylinder works well).
  4. Repeat 3–5 times and average the results to spot any deviation.
  5. Enter that ml/sec (or ml/min) rate into your dosing algorithm.

Tip: Re-calibrate whenever you change tubing length, pump voltage, or fluid viscosity.

docs.title: Assembly & Test
docs.text:
Boards purchased on Amazon are pre-assembled and tested. For DIY assembly:

  1. Solder MCU, regulator, and passives.
  2. Apply 9 V; verify 3 .3 V rail.
  3. Flash Optiboot via the UPDI header.
  4. Run blink-pump.py to toggle each MOSFET and confirm outputs.

docs.title: ED3N Hydro
docs.text:
Everything in Hydro Basic, plus Pi power-backfeed and native Atlas Scientific EZO™ support—ideal for growers upgrading from hobby probes to research-grade sensors.

!!! tip "Quick links" * Schematic PDF — download * Full BOM (CSV) — hardware/hydro/bom.csv * Buy pre-assembled on Amazon — (listing coming soon)

No soldering required — boards ship fully assembled and electrically tested.

docs.title: Feature Highlights
docs.text: MCU ATtiny1624 @ 16 MHz (Optiboot) Pump outputs 9 × N-MOSFET (8 nutrient, 1 master) · 12 V / 5 A each Raspberry Pi power 5 V / 3 A backfeed via 40-pin header• Slide switch (PI_POWER) enables/disables• Blue LED lights when 5 V rail is active Sensor inputs 8 × JST-PH I²C plus 4 × Atlas EZO™ headers Supply 9 – 15 V DC barrel jack Footprint 65 × 56 mm · 2-layer ENIG

docs.title: Powering the Raspberry Pi
docs.text:
Item Description Slide switch (PI_POWER) OFF → Pi not powered by board · ON → 5 V rail energised Blue LED Indicates Pi-power rail is on

Caution: Do not feed 5 V to the Pi from another source while PI_POWER is ON.

docs.title: Native Atlas Scientific EZO™ Support
docs.text:
Hydro includes ten Atlas headers, each four-pin:

Pin Function GND Ground 3 V3 3.3 V power SDA I²C data SCL I²C clock Header group Count Typical modules Carrier board? Carrier EZO™ 5 pH, ORP, DO, EC, RTD Yes Bare-module EZO™ 5 CO₂, O₂, Humidity, Pressure, RGB No

docs.title: Switching EZO™ boards from UART ➜ I²C
docs.text:
1. Short the I²C jumpers on each EZO board – Atlas guide: https://www.instructables.com/UART-AND-I2C-MODE-SWITCHING-FOR-ATLAS-SCIENTIFIC-E/
  2. Power-cycle → default address 0x61.
  3. Plug into any Atlas header. (Optional: use the \$13 I²C Toggler.)

docs.title: I²C capacity & best practice
docs.text:
• Pi bus handles 16 devices reliably.
  • Hydro exposes 8 JST ports + 10 Atlas headers = 18 physical ports.
  • Populate up to 16 devices total (e.g., all 10 Atlas + 6 JST) to keep signal margins.

!!! note Remove redundant consumer sensors as you migrate to Atlas probes to minimise bus load.

docs.title: Pull-up jumpers
docs.text:
Jumper Default Closed H1 (SDA) open adds 4 .7 kΩ pull-up H2 (SCL) open adds 4 .7 kΩ pull-up

Close when your sensor mix lacks pull-ups or cable runs exceed ~1 m.
